title: Continental Cutting Some Vacation Fares
description: Just days after the major airlines promised to raise fares after a bruising price war, Continental Airlines said yesterday that it would cut many summer vacation fares by an average of 25 percent on roughly half its routes.

title: 4 Shot in East New York
description: A 15-year-old boy and a 23-year-old man were shot to death and two others were wounded outside a Brooklyn housing project last night, the police said. The shooting took place at 8:30 in front of 654 Kingsborough 6th Walk in the Kingsborough Houses in East New York, said Sgt. Mary Wrensen, a police spokewoman. The wounded victims, both males, were a 17-year-old who was shot in the left leg and a 23-year-old who was shot in the left leg and torso, Sergeant Wrensen said.

title: Ripken Is Popular But Padres Merit Stars
description: In an election in which 6,622,808 fan ballots were cast and in which Cal Ripken Jr. of the Baltimore Orioles proved undoubtedly to be the people's choice by garnering the most votes, the San Diego Padres yesterday undoubtedly won fan approval as the organization with the most star quality.

title: Baghdad 'Coup': An Assassination Bid?
description: The reported coup attempt against President Saddam Hussein appears to have primarily consisted of an effort to assassinate the Iraqi leader as his motorcade was to move through the Baghdad area last week, according to an American intelligence report.

title: Mc Cluckey Favored in Trot
description: With five victories and a second in six starts this season, Mc Cluckey was made the early favorite in yesterday's post-position draw for Saturday's Yonkers Trot, the first leg of the triple crown for 3-year-old trotters.

title: Red Wings Sign 2d Generation of Howe
description: MARK HOWE said yesterday that he hopes to close his career in the city where his father became a hockey legend, signing a two-year contract with the Detroit Red Wings. The veteran defenseman said he chose Detroit because he was looking for a team with a good chance of winning the Stanley Cup in the one or two years he has left to play. Howe, 37 years old, is a son of the Hall of Famer GORDIE HOWE, who played for the Red Wings from 1946 to 1971.

title: Events: Garden Tours, Near and Far
description: Days of Day Lilies New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, Bedford Park section of the Bronx; (212) 220-8700.

title: 7 NATIONS UNABLE TO AGREE ON TRADE BUT SEE PROGRESS
description: Leaders of the world's richest industrial democracies narrowed their differences on world trade today. While they failed to reach an accord, they left the economic summit meeting here with many confident that an agreement was possible by the end of the year.

title: Consumer Debt Down
description: The nation's consumer borrowing declined $2.4 billion in May for the fourth consecutive monthly decrease, suggesting spending needed to sustain a recovery was wavering.

title:
OLYMPICS: BARCELONA PROFILE;
Marciulionis Brightens a Dawn
description: All Sarunas Marciulionis wanted to do was play basketball. He didn't want to be pulled into politics. Especially when they weren't his politics.

title: International Datacasting reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL TOUGHER ON TRADE
description: Turning aside a last-minute surge of White House lobbying, the House of Representatives today passed a broad trade bill that would require the Federal Government to adopt a more confrontational approach to reducing foreign trade barriers.

title: Fannie Mae Deal
description: The Countrywide Funding Corporation, one of the country's largest mortgage bankers, and the Federal National Mortgage Association, the Government-sponsored investor in home mortgages, signed a commitment yesterday to finance a record $8 billion of mortgages. Under the agreement, the mortgages originated by Countrywide, based in Pasadena, Calif., will be exchanged for mortgage-backed securities issued by the Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae. Countrywide will sell the securities to investors.

title: Misgivings at Glassboro, er, Rowan; Some Alumni Say Price of a $100 Million Gift Is Too High
description: Though some students and alumni protested that the price was too high, trustees of Glassboro State College today voted unanimously to rename the school after the benefactor who is giving it $100 million.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: WHAT if you dislike one or more of your child's friends? Parents pay close attention to their children's friends. Associating with "the wrong crowd" is widely viewed as a sign of trouble. But while few parents would hesitate to intervene or seek help if their child's friends were doing something illegal or self-destructive, the issue is more complicated when the problem is less clear.

title: Garden Tickets to Cost More
description: Madison Square Garden has raised ticket prices for more than half the seats at Knicks and Rangers games for the 1992-93 season, including the posh club seats, which will now carry a $75 price tag.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Laibach Limelight

title: Home Video
description: Perot on Tape

title: Stalked by Tales of Misconduct, His Promise Fading, Robb Vows to Endure
description: Once riding a fast track to power and a spot on a Democratic Presidential ticket, Senator Charles S. Robb of Virginia will play only a minor role at next week's national convention. Given the collapse of his political fortunes, it is a larger role than many party members had expected him to play.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section yesterday, about special lunches for $19.92 offered by some New York City restaurants during the Democratic National Convention, misstated the closing date for the offer. The price will last from July 13 to 16, not through the 17th.

title: It's Not the Rodney King Case
description: As the beam of the Democratic Convention spotlight swings toward New York, people all over the country have reason to wonder about the death of a young Dominican named Jose Garcia at the hands of a city police officer last Friday. Anger in his Washington Heights neighborhood has boiled over into street violence. In the wake of the Rodney King riots in Los Angeles, that leaves the quick impression of more police brutality in yet another poor community.

title: Bold Doctor Is Dismissed By a Dean
description: The outspoken doctor who oversaw the restructuring of postgraduate medical training in New York State has been dismissed as director of ambulatory-care services at Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, but will retain his tenured teaching position. His dismissal, some doctors and hospital officials say, illustrates the broad powers of hospital affiliation agreements and points to the lingering tensions over the death of Libby Zion.

title: Topics of The Times; Twain, Met
description: While scholars plunge into new debate over Huckleberry Finn's origins -- did Mark Twain, as one scholar suggests, adapt the voice of a black boy? -- only now will they be able to examine the whole work as Twain wrote it.

title: 7 Leaders Promise $1 Billion for Moscow
description: The leaders of seven major industrial democracies promised a "comprehensive partnership" with Russia and $1 billion in new aid to Moscow today. But in a meeting with the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, they signaled that the formerly Communist countries of Eastern Europe and the old Soviet Union should expect no further injections of aid until they restructured their economies.

title: Solarz Will Run in District Tailored as a Hispanic Seat
description: The effort to send a second Hispanic Representative to Congress from New York City ran into an unexpected problem today when Congressman Stephen J. Solarz, his Brooklyn base carved up in redistricting, announced that he would run in the new district drawn with the intention of electing a Hispanic member.

title: Classic Slogans Hit the Spot: Here's a Book That Has a Lot
description: "When it rains, it pours" helped sell Morton salt for decades. "Where's the beef?" enriched Wendy's by encapsulating consumer skepticism about the portions at other fast-feeders. And "In your heart you know he's right" was a rallying cry for supporters of Barry Goldwater's bid for the Presidency in 1964 -- one wickedly rejoined by those backing President Lyndon B. Johnson: "In your guts you know he's nuts."

title: For Perot, a Time of Need
description: Now is the testing time for Ross Perot. The last few weeks have battered the Texas independent's still-undeclared Presidential campaign and have stalled its momentum, causing slippage in the polls and worry here in the offices of the Perot Petition Committee, a suite of rooms with a clean, shiny just-unwrapped look.

title: Lease Deal By Airbus And United
description: United Airlines, long the most loyal and biggest customer of the Boeing Company, yesterday said it had leased 50 planes from Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European consortium battling Boeing's world dominance in commercial aircraft.

title: Police Clear Protesters' Trucks Off French Roads
description: A 10-day protest by truckers who blocked traffic on scores of French highways petered out today under pressure from heavily armed riot police. But the real loser may be the Socialist Government, which has emerged from the dispute with its image badly bruised.

title: DeKalb Genetics reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
REVLON REDUCES SIZE OF STOCK OFFERING
description: Revlon Inc., the cosmetics company controlled by Ronald O. Perelman, yesterday reduced its planned common stock offering to 11 million shares from 20 million. The company, based in New York, also reduced the proposed share price to $14 to $15 each from $19, meaning the sale will produce about $144 million instead of almost $400 million as originally planned. The reduction will also leave Mr. Perelman with a larger stake in the company than under the original plan.

title: Rangers Trade Kerr to Whalers
description: General Manager NEIL SMITH of the Rangers cut his losses yesterday on a disappointing acquisition, sending right wing TIM KERR to Hartford for an undisclosed draft pick.

title: Horizon Healthcare reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 88,000, or 1 cent a share.The company attributed its improved earnings in the latest quarter to newly acquired facilities, increases in reinbursement from the Medicaid and Medicare programs and a stronger contribution from higher margin specialty services and programs.

title: Washington at Work; Stalked by Tales of Misconduct, His Promise Fading, Robb Vows to Endure
description: Once riding a fast track to power and a spot on a Democratic Presidential ticket, Senator Charles S. Robb of Virginia will play only a minor role at next week's national convention. Given the collapse of his political fortunes, it is a larger role than many party members had expected him to play.

title: Media General reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Included a gain of about $ 900,000, or 3 cents a share, from certain insurance proceeds related to an October 1991 fire for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Market Place; Polygram Stock Climbs the Charts
description: AN annual record awards ceremony in Britain last month was a particularly sweet occasion for Polygram Records, the unit of Philips N.V. that sold 20 percent of its stock to the public two years ago.

title: Queens Democrats Oppose Flake in Primary
description: In a highly unusual move, the Queens Democratic organization has decided to oppose the renomination of Representative Floyd H. Flake and to back his opponent, Simeon Golar, in the Democratic primary in September.

title: Rabin's Call: What's a Housing Start?
description: From a welter of numbers made public this week, it is beginning to appear that if Yitzhak Rabin is serious about scaling back settlement activity in the occupied territories, he may want to bring along statisticians and attorneys when he moves into the Prime Minister's office.

title: Chronicle
description: It took a while for JOANNE TOOR CUMMINGS to fully appreciate the avant-garde works of ROBERT WILSON, the theatrical and operatic director, playwright and designer. Some of his productions run as long as 24 hours, but over the years Mrs. Cummings has become an unabashed admirer.

title: Vanderbilt Gold Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Business Failures Up
description: United States business failures rose 15.9 percent for the first five months of 1992, Dun & Bradstreet said yesterday. Business failures for the period totaled 42,118, up from 36,355 in January through May 1991.

title: There He Goes Again: Carter Hits 19th
description: Blue Jays 6, Mariners 0

title: Candidates On Television
description: The Presidential campaigners have scheduled these television appearances in coming days: President Bush

title: Books of The Times; Most of What People Say About Trash Is Rubbish
description: Rubbish! The Archeology of Garbage By William Rathje and Cullen Murphy Illustrated. 250 pages. HarperCollins. $23.

title: Intel Invests In VLSI
description: In an effort to cement its position in the emerging market for hand-held computers, the Intel Corporation invested $50 million today in VLSI Technology Inc., a chip maker based in San Jose, Calif., that designs custom-based semiconductors.

title: Records at N.F.L. Trial Show Jets and Giants in the Red
description: From 1986 through 1989, before the National Football League landed the richest television sports deal ever, the Giants and the Jets were consistent financial losers, according to the teams' financial records.

title: George Sawyer Sr., 66, Scientist and Educator
description: Dr. George C. Sawyer Sr., a chemical engineer and drug developer who became an executive, professor and proponent of corporate social responsibility, died July 2 at the Butterfield Hospital in Cold Spring, N.Y. He was 66 years old and lived in Garrison, N.Y.

title: Ted Einstein, 68; Built a Carpet Chain With the Moomjys
description: Ted Einstein, a founding partner in Einstein Moomjy, the carpet-store chain, died on Sunday at his home in Morristown, N.J. He was 68 years old.

title: N.Y.R.A. Trustees Approve Lot Sale
description: The peace treaty between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the management of New York's three major race tracks was confirmed yesterday by the trustees of the New York Racing Association.

title: AT HOME WITH: Jeremy Railton; Setting the Scene For an Actor to Steal
description: THE rooms in Jeremy Railton's Mediterranean-style house in West Hollywood seem to have sprung magically off a sketch pad and leaped onto a movie screen. Or maybe it's the other way around.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Anthem Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Chronicle
description: Woody Guthrie, the balladeer of the Depression era, would have turned 80 next week. So on Sunday, his son ARLO GUTHRIE and his compatriot PETE SEEGER will perform in Central Park, along with other musicians who have followed in his footsteps, including SUZANNE VEGA, NANCI GRIFFITH, BILLY BRAGG and the Disposable Heroes of Hiphoprisy. The Summerstage concert will take place at 2 P.M. at Rumsey Playfield off 72d Street, west of Fifth Avenue.

title: DURR SHARES SURGE BEYOND BERGEN'S TAKEOVER BID
description: The shares of Durr-Fillauer Medical Inc. surged passed the unsolicited $26-a-share cash offer by the Bergen Brunswig Corporation on expectations that a higher bid would surface. The offer by Bergen is valued at $310 million. In over-the-counter trading yesterday, Durr-Fillauer's stock rose $5.25, or 23.6 percent, to $27.50. "The market is definitely anticipating that the bid for Durr-Fillauer will be sweetened," said Don Spindel, an analyst at A. G. Edwards & Sons. Durr-Fillauer, based in Montgomery, Ala., is the focus of a bidding contest between the medical product distributors Bergen Brunswig and Cardinal Distribution Inc.

title: High-Tech Equipment Finds Ready Takers
description: As the ball continues to fly farther and straighter in professional golf, the role of technological advances in equipment has become the center of an intense debate.

title: Exabyte Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
British Airways On USAir Deal
description: British Airways P.L.C. said today that it was looking at several possible deals with other carriers but declined comment on whether it was holding specific discussions with the USAir Group.

title: Amoco Is Cutting 8,500 Jobs
description: The Amoco Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest oil company, said yesterday that it would eliminate 8,500 jobs, 15.7 percent of its 54,120 employees, by the end of the year.

title: Settlement in Austin's Lawsuit
description: TRACY AUSTIN, a two-time United States Open champion, will get $1.35 million in a settlement of her lawsuit that charged that a 1989 auto accident in Morristown, N.J., ended her comeback. Austin suffered a broken leg and neck and back injuries when her car was struck by a van driven by STEVEN M. REYNOLLS on Aug. 3, 1989, court papers say. She was trying to come back from a five-year absence brought on by a bad back. The 29-year-old Austin was playing team tennis for the New Jersey Stars franchise.

title: Browsers Are Welcome
description: AT Entree Libre, a new contemporary-furnishings store in SoHo, browsing is encouraged, as if the shop were indeed an open book. The quirky, limited-edition items inside are made by a roster of international designers.

title: State-O-Maine Inc.(X) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March 1992.

title: Bridge
description: Leading partner's suit is normal, but it should never be done without thought. A case in point is the diagramed deal from "Dear Billy," a collection of 47 deals. The author is Billy Miller, and the book is obtainable from him at 3014 Badger Drive, Pleasanton, Calif. 94566 for $11.20.

title: Bound to Looms by Poverty and Fear, Boys in India Make a Few Men Rich
description: As the summer sun labored toward the desiccated plains of northern India, Amarnath Kumar, a straw-thin 10-year-old boy, and three friends crept away from the red adobe hut that had been their prison for 18 months. Across the blistered soil of fallow wheat fields, the boys hurried north, avoiding other people, hurrying into the descending darkness.

title: Benihana National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
description: b-Included income of $ 353,000, or 6 cents a share, from cumulative effect of change in accounting principle for both the quarter and year.Sales represented net restaurant sales.

title: Yields on Money Funds Fall After Discount Rate Is Pared
description: After the Federal Reserve cut the discount rate last week, yields dropped sharply on tax-exempt money market funds and fell less severely for taxable funds, IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report said.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Jimmy Buffet Jones Beach Theater Wantagh, L.I.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN wooden floorboards are so badly stained or damaged that refinishing will not restore them, they should be replaced. Replacing floorboards requires modest carpentry skills but is within the range of most amateurs.

title: 60's Cigarette In Comeback
description: To help revive Lark, a cigarette brand popular in the 1960's, the Liggett Group and its agency, Bloom FCA in Dallas, are introducing a national print campaign featuring product-selling ideas from that period.

title: Topics of The Times; Toying With Labels
description: The Bush Administration's moratorium on new regulations has undermined at least one small reassurance to parents. The Consumer Product Safety Commission, despite a staff study to the contrary, recently rejected a rule that would require clear warning labels on small toys that can choke young children. That pleased some toy manufacturers, who fear the warning labels might hurt business. The commission would do better to worry about parts that hurt children.

title: The Talk of Hollywood; Hollywood Hot Topic: Japanese Cold Feet
description: Are the Japanese growing queasy about Hollywood? The question has stirred the town this summer, less than three years after the start of a spending spree by the Sony Corporation and, to a lesser degree, the Mat sushita Electrical Industrial Company, that amazed even Hollywood. If the marriage between Japan and Hollywood seemed, from the outset, a bit shaky, the strains have now left the participants anxious and defensive.

title: Bush Staff Lawyer's Call On Iraq Case Is Reported
description: A lawyer on President Bush's legal staff discussed the criminal investigation of an Atlanta bank's loans to Iraq with the Federal prosecutor supervising the case at least once in late 1989 and perhaps on a number of occasions, the senior Assistant United States Attorney in Atlanta said today.

title: Economic Scene; Who Will Pay, If Not Japan?
description: THIS economic news just in from Munich: Leaders of the industrial powers have affirmed, in principle, their support for open trade, stable growth and aid for the former Soviet Union.

title: Unitrin Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included gains from sales of investments of $ 1.2 million in the quarter and $ 2.1 million in the 6 months.c-Included gains from sales of investments of $ 600,000 in the quarter and $ 9.2 million in the 6 months.The company said storm losses in the latest second quarter exceeded storm losses in the year-ago quarter by $ 12.7 million after-tax.The company also said that the second quarter of 1991 was adversely impacted by an after-tax charge of $ 19.8 million representing Unitrin's equity share of Litton Industries Inc.'s phase-down of certain operations.

title: Rockefeller Enters Race for Senate
description: New York's newest United States Senate candidate officially began his campaign yesterday with a Jerry Brown-style appeal for volunteers to call a toll-free number and a vow to shun television commercials in his bid to oust the Republican incumbent, Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Review/Opera; Kirov Confirms Mythology of Russian Tradition
description: During the cold war, Western opera fans clung to a mythology about the state of opera in the Soviet Union that held that the Russian tradition was being carefully preserved along with the distinctive vocal style that gave that tradition its life. Recordings supported this belief, yet when the cold war ended the myth proved fragile. Tour performances in the last year by the Bolshoi Opera and the St. Petersburg National Opera left operagoers to wonder whether tales of Soviet operatic prowess were the creations of some obscure cultural branch of the Pentagon.

title: In Quest to Help the Middle Class, House Passes a College Loan Bill
description: Trumpeting its allegiance to middle-class Americans, the House today passed and sent to President Bush legislation to help them get more college loans.

title: Collaborative Research Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
'Savior' Tells Olympia Its U.S. Unit Defaulted
description: Li Ka-shing, a Hong Kong billionaire and partner of Olympia & York Developments Ltd. in several properties, has notified the company's American subsidiary that it defaulted on a $57.5 million mortgage on a lower Manhattan office building.

title: Pretoria Can Stop the Killings at Any Time; Action by de Klerk
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Expands Pesticide Ban To Cover Many Used in Food
description: Seeking to resolve one of the most difficult scientific and legal conflicts involving the nation's food supply, a Federal Court of Appeals ruled today that the Environmental Protection Agency must remove from the market any pesticides that both have the potential to cause cancer and leave residues in processed foods.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: 5 Are Indicted in Computer Credit Theft
description: A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted five New York computer hackers on charges of breaking into some of the most sensitive computers used by telephone companies and major credit reporting services and disrupting or stealing their data. It is one of the most extensive thefts of computer information on record, Federal authorities said.

title: SUMMIT IN MUNICH -- Yeltsin's Song: Summit Blues; 7 Pats on the Back -- And Some Token Aid
description: Boris N. Yeltsin's journey to Munich was familiar: the preliminary vow that he would not "get on his knees" before the West, an encouraging pat from leaders of the rich world, a handful of change and promises of far more once he really got moving on reforms.

title: Japan Tool Orders Fall
description: Orders to Japanese machine tool manufacturers in May fell to 58.824 billion yen, or $471 million, down 42.3 percent from May 1991 and 8.3 percent from the previous month, the Japan Machine Tool Builders Association said today. Month-to-month orders fell 12.3 percent in April after rising 3 percent in February and 16 percent in March.

title: Fight on Trenton Aid to Poor School Districts Goes to Court, Again
description: Two years after the New Jersey Supreme Court ordered that school spending in the state's poorest districts be brought up to the level of the most affluent, lawyers returned to court today to argue about whether the resulting legislation is doing the job.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Breathing Trees

title: ConAgra Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said year-ago results are restated to reflect pooling of interests with Golden Valley Microwave Foods Inc.Shares outstanding for the year-ago quarter and year reflects a 3-for-2 stock split effective Dec. 2, 1991.

title: Perot's Standard Campaign Speech: 'Plain Texas Talk' About 'People Power'
description: Ross Perot, whose flirtation with an independent Presidential candidacy has shaken the political establishment of both parties, likes to boast that he has no handlers, no "spin doctors" and, most important, no speech writers.

title: Reavis Cox, 91, Dies; A Marketing Authority
description: Reavis Cox, an internationally recognized marketing authority and former chairman of the department of marketing at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, died on Saturday at his home in Swarthmore, Pa. He was 91 years old.

title: Review/Music; The 'Mostly' Festival Opens With All Mozart
description: What, at this late date, can be said about Mozart that hasn't already been said during the past two years of celebrations honoring the bicentennial of the composer's death? Are there many who yearn for seven weeks more of his music after so much has been heard so intensely? And what, given Lincoln Center's encyclopedic scheduling of every work, is yet to be heard that hasn't already been heard?

title: G.M. Signs an Accord With Environmentalists
description: In an unusual expression of detente between industry and environmentalists, General Motors and the Environmental Defense Fund announced yesterday that they had signed an agreement to hold formal discussions on environmental issues.

title: Dinkins, Amid Crowd, Nurtures Fragile Peace
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins's visit to Washington Heights yesterday was the latest example of an aggressive strategy to restore peace through broad symbolic acts and small administrative actions.

title: Audiovox Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 509,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 863,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 6 months.c-Net loss

title: Hospital Data Show Increase In Drug Abuse
description: After showing modest signs of improvement, the drug situation in New York City has taken a turn for the worse, state officials said yesterday. Hospital treatment of heroin and cocaine cases is up sharply, they said, and some dealers are expanding their operations and dropping prices.

title: Washington State Journal; Where Nobody Is Absolutely Real
description: With voter discontent sloshing around at the high tide mark this political season, somebody is actually trying to do something about all the frustration. That somebody is Nobody.

title: 4 Companies Cut PC Prices
description: Price wars in the consumer personal computer market intensified again yesterday when the Digital Equipment Corporation, one of the world's biggest computer makers, and the Compuadd Computer Corporation, a relative newcomer in the PC market, slashed prices to below $1,000 for low-end PC's.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: DEBT * Public Service Co. of Oklahoma, Tulsa, Okla., a unit of Central and South West Corp., is offering $65 million of 7 1/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 2003 at 98.991 to yield 7.28 percent through Merrill Lynch & Co. The bonds are rated Aa-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA- by Standard & Poor's Corp. * Comcast Corp., Philadelphia, is offering $300 million of 10 5/8 percent senior subordinated debentures due in 2012 at par through Merrill Lynch & Co. The noncallable issue is rated B-1 by Moody's and B by S.& P. * International Lease Finance Corp., Beverly Hills, Calif., a unit of American International Group, is offering $150 million of 6 1/2 percent notes due in 1997 at 99.796 to yield 6.549 percent through Salomon Brothers. The noncallable notes are rated A-2 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P. * Continental Homes Holding Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of $75 million of senior notes through Kidder, Peabody & Co. PREFERRED * BankAmericaCorp., San Francisco, is offering 16 million preferred shares at $25 a share to yield 8.16 percent through Merrill Lynch & Co. Noncallable for five years, the preferred stock is rated A-2 by Moody's and BBB+ by S.& P.

title: Burlington Resources
description: Burlington Resources Inc., an energy and natural resources company whose operations include a natural gas pipeline system, said on Tuesday that Donald W. Clayton had been elected president. He succeeds Thomas H. O'Leary, who remains chairman and chief executive. Mr. Clayton will remain president and chief executive of Meridan Oil Inc.

title: Women Candidates Have to Run Scared; Voter Turnout
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Candidates Have to Run Scared
description: To the Editor:

title: A.T.&T. Prices $500 Million Of 8 1/8%, 32-Year Debentures
description: A.T.& T. priced $500 million of 32-year debentures yesterday through an underwriting group led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: COMPANY NEWS: For the Shirt-Pocket Library; The Trivial to the Arcane In 10 Easy Megabytes
description: As part of its endless quest to expand the carrying capacity of shirt pockets, Franklin Electronic Publishers Inc. this fall will introduce a portable electronic reference library.

title: Lebanese Plan the Return of War Refugees
description: The Government announced today that it would begin returning hundreds of thousands of refugees who were forced to flee their homes at the outset of the Lebanese civil war 17 years ago.

title: Au Pair's Acquittal Leaves Anger, Recriminations and Mysteries
description: Hours after a Swiss au pair was acquitted of killing the baby in her care, participants at her trial were raising questions about the mysteries of the case.

title: Timetable on Lawsuit Seems a Setback for Cubs
description: The Federal judge presiding over the Chicago Cubs' lawsuit seeking an injunction against Commissioner Fay Vincent set a schedule yesterday for submission of papers that will not meet the Cubs' request that Vincent's forced realignment of the National League be stopped before July 20.

title: A Careful Touch Is Needed When Repairing Rosewood Furniture
description: Rosewood has always been one of the most cherished woods. Named for the roselike odor that it gives off when cut, rosewood can be readily recognized by its warm reddish appearance and pronounced wavy black streaks. Rosewood's distinctive appearance, and price, have made it a popular wood to copy, a procedure that has usually resulted in exaggerated colors and markings.

title: W. B. Doner Wins Chiquita Account
description: W. B. Doner & Company in Baltimore and Southfield, Mich., said yesterday that it had been awarded the European advertising account of the Chiquita Banana Company B.V., Rotterdam, the Netherlands, a unit of Chiquita Brands International, with billings estimated at $10 million.

title: Cara Operations reports earnings for Qtr to June 21
description: Results are fully diluted.

title: New York Deserves Better Than the News Coverage It Gets
description: To the Editor:

title: Lincoln Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Pretoria Can Stop the Killings at Any Time
description: To the Editor:

title: The Suburban Presence in Uniform
description: Beyond the question of Officer Michael O'Keefe's guilt or innocence in the killing of a young Dominican man last week, the clashes between the police and Hispanic residents in Washington Heights have exposed a fundamental tension found in precincts in many parts of the city.

title: Japan, Citing Recent Accident, Delays Launching
description: In another serious setback for Japan's budding space program, the Government announced today that it would delay the initial launching of its next-generation rocket by one year because of a recent accident.

title: ExecuFirst Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included $ 628,295 of securities gains.

title: Women Candidates Have to Run Scared; Maine Women
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. WILL MARKET SOFTWARE FOR BIG RETAIL OPERATIONS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation will market the software system developed by Federated Department Stores Inc., whose retail chains include Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus, to keep track of large retail operations. I.B.M. will operate and maintain computer systems and networks for clients, while Federated will provide the Sabre software.

title: CFCF Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: Premier Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KODAK SEEKS SALE OF GOVERNMENT HIGH-TECH DIVISION
description: The Ball Corporation might buy the Eastman Kodak Company's division that researches and supplies high-technology equipment for the Federal Government, the companies said yesterday.

title: Waterloo Violinist Cancels
description: Sarah Chang, a violinist, has canceled her appearance with the Waterloo Festival Orchestra at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N.J., on Saturday evening because of an injury. Anne Akiko Meyers will replace her as soloist in the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto, under the direction of Karl Anton Rickenbacherl. The rest of the program remains unchanged: "Un Sourire" by Messiaen, and the Brahms Fourth Symphony. The concert begins at 8:30 P.M. Information: (201) 347-4700.

title: First Empire State reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The bank said its latest quarter included $ 7.6 million of after-tax gains on sales of bank investment securities. The 1992 6 month results included $ 16.1 million of after-tax securities gains.

title: Hope Is in the Mail
description: AT the John Heuss House, a drop-in center in downtown Manhattan, homeless men and women regain strength and promise. The care and concern extended to visitors is reflected in note cards designed by artists to raise money for the center.

title: REXENE MOVES CLOSER TO ENDING CHAPTER 11 BANKRUPTCY
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge confirmed a reorganization plan for the Rexene Corporation yesterday, clearing the way for the Dallas-based petrochemicals company to emerge from bankruptcy by the end of the summer. The plan will reduce Rexene's debt to about $337 million in new long-term notes, eliminating the $403 million in junk bonds the company defaulted on last year.

title: Navy Investigator Removed From Inquiry on Assaults
description: A naval investigator looking into the assault of 26 women at a naval aviators' convention last year was removed from the case and disciplined after one of the victims complained that the agent was pressuring her to see him socially, the Navy said today.

title: Safeway Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 13
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 27,800,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "There are no specific agreements on anything in the final declaration." -- PRIME MINISTER JOHN MAJOR, at the end of the summit conference in Munich. [ A12:5. ]

title: Sonoco Products Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Included a gain of $ 4.5 million, or 10 cents a share, on the sale of the company's interest in Sonoco Graham Co. for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Artwork That Stands Tall
description: CONSTANCE LESLIE works mostly with clay, but dislikes the label ceramicist. "A ceramicist often implies a potter," she said. "I work with other materials as well, like glass and stone."

title: Funds Pact Would Avoid More Cutbacks in Schools
description: The New York City school system will be able to stabilize class sizes and stave off cuts in the teaching staff under a budget agreement with City Hall and the state that appears close to completion, senior Board of Education and city officials said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Port Authority Tries to Save Passenger Tax at 3 Airports
description: Federal transportation officials have threatened to reject a $3 passenger tax that would finance $1.5 billion in mass transit links at Newark, La Guardia and Kennedy Airports, but they have left the Port Authority baffled over the reason for the problem.

title: Commerce Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to month 00
Essay; Obstructing Justice
description: In 1958 Sherman Adams, Eisenhower's chief of staff, improperly called the S.E.C. from the White House to inquire about the status of an investigation into his friend Bernard Goldfine; that influential call led to scandal and prosecutions.

title: Review/Television; 'The Real World,' According to MTV
description: Billed as a reality-based soap opera, MTV's "Real World" is real largely by accident, and its seven principal players are far too independent to be stuffed into a tidy little soap opera. Yet this force-fed documentary series, reaching the 9th of its 13 half-hour episodes tonight at 10, has been steadily evolving into the year's most riveting television, a compelling portrait of twentysomethings grappling with the 90's.

title: Lindros's First Opponent? The Nordiques
description: ERIC LINDROS will be on the ice with the Quebec Nordiques in his National Hockey League debut if he has signed with Philadelphia by then. The Flyers host the Nordiques in their preseason opener Sept. 19. The teams will face each other again the next night, this time in Quebec.

title: Digging Up the Mystical Through Mazes
description: IN 1989, Alex Champion decided to trade in his test tubes for a shovel.

title: Japanese Cannot Wait to Hear the Cry 'Play Ball!'
description: One thing everyone should understand early about the Japanese team that looms as a strong contender for the first Olympic gold medal ever awarded in baseball: It's not just a game to these guys.

title: Northwest Most Timely
description: Northwest Airlines had the best on-time performance among major United States airlines in May, the Transportation Department said today. Northwest flew 93.1 percent of its flights on time in May. Southwest Airlines was second with 92.9 percent of its flights arriving on time, and America West Airlines was third with 91.4 percent on time. USAir had the worst on-time record in May with 82.4 percent of its flights on schedule.

title: Banponce Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Electronics, Missiles & Communications reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 62,000, or 1 cent a share and also included is the initial payment for the sale of a rural cellular license of $ 845,000, net of closing costs of $ 155,000.

title: Tokyo Slide Has No Shock Wave
description: Just a few years ago, lots of people worried that a financial collapse in Tokyo would devastate financial markets and economies everywhere, and nowhere more than in the United States.

title: Tool Dumping By Japanese
description: Makita and other Japanese makers of electric machine tools are illegally dumping products on United States markets, the International Trade Commission ruled today at a preliminary hearing.

title: Hamptons Bancshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Roadway Services reports earnings for 12wks to June 20
Desanka Mohorovicic, Lifeboat Mother, 78
description: Desanka Mohorovicic, who made front-page news in 1942 by giving birth in a crowded lifeboat off North Carolina after the American ship she was traveling on was sunk by a submarine, died last Thursday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. She was 78 years old and lived in River Edge, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday, about a garden reception to be given at Gracie Mansion on Sunday by Ethel Kennedy, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins to commemorate the 25th anniversary of Robert F. Kennedy's last campaign, included a name erroneously among those who said they would attend. Douglas Dillon, a supporter of President Bush, does not plan to attend.

title: New Campaigns
description: * Louie Anderson is starring in television commercials to promote Northwest Airlines' customer service, as part of the airline's recently introduced campaign carrying the theme, "Some people just know how to fly." The spots, created by J. Walter Thompson, New York, feature the comedian as a weary business traveler. In one, he sits, stranded and suffering, on another airline as a continuous stream of Northwest flights depart on time. * The American Olympic decathlete Dave Johnson and the middle-distance runner Suzy Hamilton endorse Pert shampoo in television commercials created by Leo Burnett U.S.A., Chicago. The spots carry the tag line: "Performance. No Fuss."

title: For This Paris Designer, All the World's a Studio
description: IT'S the kind of place that makes you feel as if you have just discovered a secret source, like an explorer entering a forest of still-to-be-named flora.

title: Cardiac Control reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CBS Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 12,900,000, or 75 cents a share.

title: Western Bank reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Paint Jobs for Appliances and Tubs
description: APPLIANCES are often the first thing you notice in a kitchen, particularly if they're faded, scratched or painted a color that was in style 20 years ago. But like walls and furniture, appliances can be painted and rehabilitated to look new.

title: In Unrest, a Dominican Leader Steps Into Spotlight
description: At a news conference on the lawn of Gracie Mansion this week, City Councilman Guillermo Linares, his arm around the bereaved matriarch of the family of Jose Luis Garcia, gingerly plucked the microphone from Mayor David N. Dinkins.

title: 2 Incumbents Yield 1 Victor
description: Representative Bob McEwen, a House member since 1980, was declared the winner today by 286 votes of 66,000 cast in a primary on June 2 that pitted him against fellow Republican Representative Clarence E. Miller. It was the only primary in the country this year pitting two Republican members of the House against each other because of redistricting.

title: In Her Brightening Glance, a Community Sways
description: Lost in a whirl all her own, Dena Spurling spun, then fluttered her chiffon wings before soaring above the floor in a solo she had practiced to near perfection.

title: Marriott Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 19
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Restaurants
description: Josephina is Manhattan's newest and most ambitious health-oriented restaurant -- well, sort of. True, the kitchen does not fry, eschews most dairy products and serves mountains of crunchy greens and grains that act as little snowplows of the arteries. Yet you can still get a hamburger at lunch, a fatty Long Island duck at dinner and egg-thickened creme brulee anytime.

title: If You're Hungry For Still More Politics
description: Here are some convention-related events, open to the public, in New York City. Today

title: European Envoy to Ask Balkan Leaders to Talks
description: The European Community's chief negotiator for Yugoslavia said today that he would invite the leaders of the three competing sides from Bosnia and Herzegovina for a fresh round of peace talks in London.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats; CLINTON SELECTS SENATOR GORE OF TENNESSEE AS RUNNING MATE
description: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas today selected Senator Al Gore of Tennessee to join him as his Vice-Presidential running mate when he receives the Democratic nomination for President in New York next week.

title: Gay Pride Parents
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Debut; Mrs. Clinton Introduces Mrs. Gore At Children's Hospital Ceremony
description: In the first "family values" tableau of the Clinton-Gore ticket, Hillary Clinton took Tipper Gore with her to visit the Arkansas Children's Hospital in Little Rock.

title: Traffic Alert
description: TOMORROW

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was only hours before her name was announced around the world via satellite yesterday that GRACA SIMBINE MACHEL learned she was one of two winners of the 1992 Africa Prize for Leadership for the Sustainable End of Hunger. Speaking from her home in Maputo, Mozambique, she said: "My first question was, 'Me?' They said yes, so I said, 'Why me?"

title: Slaney Pulls Out
description: MARY SLANEY, suffering from a virus, yesterday withdrew from her planned confrontation against ZOLA BUDD PIETERSE in a 2,000-meter race at the TSB track and field meet in London. The two were to compete today in their first meeting in seven years. They last raced against each other in Europe in 1985, a year after Slaney tripped on Pieterse's barefoot heel in the 3,000-meter final at the Los Angeles Olympics. (AP)

title: Hunger Ebbs in Sarajevo, but Fear of Serbs Rises
description: As the United States and other Western nations continue to debate ways of protecting and expanding the United Nations relief effort to this besieged city, Sarajevans are thinking less about their hunger than about the risk that the city will be captured by the Serbian forces attacking it.

title: Festival Featuring Hip-Hop Dancing
description: When the hip-hop choreographer Jamale Graves brings his troupe of dancers to the stage of Alice Tully Hall tomorrow night as part of Lincoln Center's Serious Fun festival, it will be a turning point in the evolution of urban street dance. Break dancing, a genre that is struggling for respectability after having nearly been exploited to death as a commercial fad, is being officially blessed by Lincoln Center, which has commissioned Mr. Graves's newest work.

title: Review/Film; A Kiss Turns Into the Unexpected
description: "Prelude to a Kiss," adapted by Craig Lucas from his successful play and directed by Norman Rene, who directed the stage production, is a contemporary romantic comedy with the heart of a very dark fable. It's "Beauty and the Beast" with a wicked twist, in which Beauty becomes a beast and it's the prince's love, not Beauty's, that is put to the test.

title: Boy Wins Right to Sue Parents for Separation
description: In a decision that could significantly broaden children's rights if upheld, a juvenile court judge in Orlando ruled today that an 11-year-old boy has the legal right to sue for separation from his parents.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about Maj. Gen. Lewis W. MacKenzie, commander of United Nations forces in Bosnia and Herzegovina, referred incorrectly to the transporting of a Serbian official into Sarajevo in a United Nations armored vehicle. It was a subordinate, not General MacKenzie himself, who made the vehicle available to the Serbian official.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SEARS, ROEBUCK & CO., Chicago, hired Neil Hartigan, a former Illinois Attorney General, as an adviser on issues relating to Sears Auto Centers. STOP & SHOP COMPANIES completed the sale of its about 11 million shares of Bradlees Inc. to underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Co. and received net proceeds of about $135 million.

title: House Panel Urges Special Counsel for Iraq Inquiry
description: The House Judiciary Committee today requested the appointment of an independent counsel to investigate whether the Bush Administration broke Federal laws in executing and defending its policy toward Iraq.

title: Social Comment on Film
description: Here is a sampling of political films to be shown in the New York metropolitan area during the convention. Today

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Olympia Gets Court Delay
description: The Ontario Court of Justice ruled today that Olympia & York Developments Ltd. had until Aug. 21 to file a restructuring plan. Olympia was to have filed the plan by Monday.

title: Pol Pot Against the U.N.
description: Remember last year's Cambodia peace agreement? World leaders congratulated themselves that they had helped negotiate an end to 20-plus years of carnage.

title: Regards From Broadway
description: Here is the maddening quandary of the would-be Broadway playgoer at the Democratic National Convention: how to attend delegates' sessions every night while managing to conduct a democratic sampling of plays and musicals?

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's 589 money market mutual funds increased by $23.73 billion, to $496.03 billion, for the seven-day period that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 217 institutional funds increased $19.65 billion, to $185.25 billion.

title: Children In Crisis Can Play At Court
description: In a setting that could pass for a day care center, children clamber on a Jungle Gym, play with stuffed animals and shoot pool, but the fun belies the somber reason they are here, at the new Los Angeles County Children's Court. Most are waiting to find out whether they will be taken from their parents.

title: Partners in the Slave Trade
description: At the summit meeting of the Organization of African Unity in Senegal last week, the Rev. Jesse Jackson proposed that Africa be compensated for the losses inflicted by the slave trade. He said the plan would be comparable to aid given to Eastern Europe and reparations paid to Jewish survivors of the Holocaust.

title: Barcelona or Bust: Stockton Gets Clearance
description: JOHN STOCKTON was cleared by Utah Jazz doctors yesterday to resume play with the United States Olympic basketball team. The All-Star point guard went to Salt Lake City on Wednesday to be examined by the team's orthopedic surgeon, Dr. LYLE MASON. He said Stockton's injury, an undisplaced fracture of the right proximal fibula, is healing well.

title: Natural Gas Vehicle Fleets? An Offer of Free Conversion
description: To help stimulate the market for natural gas as a vehicle fuel, Mesa Inc. said yesterday that it would convert commercial or government vehicle fleets to natural gas at no charge and install fueling stations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Sir IAN McKELLEN, who has taken his Richard III from New York to the Kennedy Center in Washington, crawled out of a sick bed on Wednesday to address members of the National Press Club at a luncheon at the group's headquarters.

title: Candidates On Television
description: The Presidential campaigners have scheduled these television appearances in coming days: President Bush

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on April 28 with an article about the outlook for Peru's copper industry misidentified the equipment shown. It is a converter furnace, not a crusher. The Southern Peru Copper Corporation wrote to The Times about the error on May 11, but the letter was misplaced through an editing lapse.

title: Protesters On Abortion To Be Stifled
description: In a sweeping injunction intended to block attempts by the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue to either disrupt the Democratic National Convention or cut off access to New York City abortion clinics, a Federal District Court yesterday imposed restrictions that promise to cripple the group's efforts here.

title: Alberta Jacoby, Film Maker, 80; Lecturer at Yale
description: Alberta Smith Jacoby, a film maker and lecturer on mental health, died on Wednesday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. She was 80 years old and lived in Guilford, Conn.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Man in the News; A Man Who Was Raised to Be the President: Albert Arnold Gore Jr.
description: When he announced last summer that he would not run for President this year, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee said he had too many family responsibilities. But Mr. Gore left no doubt about his ultimate ambition.

title: Ross Perot: Hero of the Counterculture
description: Ross Perot reverses the usual process by which we measure political value. The parts of the man are worth more than the whole. His flashing insights into how America functions -- and what's wrong when it doesn't -- are goldfish in the mudhole of what stands for political discourse in this country.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Looking Back; '88 Campaign Provided Hard Lessons for Gore
description: He won seven primaries and caucuses. He was one of only three Democratic contenders still standing after the major Southern contests. But the most memorable moments from Senator Al Gore's failed bid for President in 1988 were also his most humiliating.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: News Analysis; Behind Clinton's Choice
description: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas has set himself a mighty task: nothing less than the rejuvenation of the Democratic Party.

title: INSIDE
description: Breach of Budget Act Voted

title: Drug Test Charges
description: NATALYA ARTYOMOVA of the Commonwealth of Independent States, one of the world's top middle-distance runners, has been accused of trying to manipulate her drug sample Saturday night at the Bislett Games.

title: Desert Storm, Diamond Calm
description: Just listen to the Top Guy on his finest innings: "I'd like to hit the rewind button for you and go back to late 1989, when we began to formulate the strategy that is now on the street. . . . The first thing we concluded was that the world was still a dangerous place. . . . Our public saw the very best and brightest of our youth . . . and the country fell in love. . . . The name of the game is winning."

title: Market Place; Reading the Candidates And Reading the Dow
description: Buy stocks, unless you think Ross Perot is going to be so strong as to upset the apple cart and significantly affect the election. Or unless you think a new recession will have begun by Election Day.

title: A Torch Passes in Little Rock
description: When Gov. Bill Clinton introduced Senator Al Gore as his running mate yesterday, Mr. Gore stressed that it was time for a new generation of leaders to replace those he said had run out of energy and ideas. The Democratic candidates, both in their mid-40's, do indeed present a youthful contrast to George Bush and Ross Perot, both in their 60's. But more important than any age difference are the historical forces that have shaped this younger generation of political leaders, the first to be born and grow to maturity after World War II.

title:
Single-Family Homes;
2 Projects Get a Reprieve And Prices Are Lowered
description: Two single-family home projects derailed by the recession are back on track again here with new models and lower prices to make them more salable.

title: Lifetime Ban for Nilsen?
description: Shot-putter LARS NILSEN of Norway, a bronze medalist last year at the world championships, faces a lifetime ban from track and field after testing positive for use of banned drugs for a second time, it was reported yesterday.

title: Convention Costs Keep Going Up and Away
description: Three days before the Democratic National Convention opens, the costly reality of putting on a show in New York City has sunk in.

title: Now a Money Pit Endangers U.S. Open Construction Plans
description: The United States Tennis Association's controversial plans to construct a modern site for the United States Open adjacent to the current location at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park are once again in jeopardy. This time it is financing, rather than site selection or political snafus or architectural details, that is causing dissension over a project whose construction was originally scheduled to begin this year but continues to idle.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about House approval of legislation providing financial aid to college students referred incorrectly to action by a House Appropriations subcommittee. The committee moved to cut Pell grants to $2,300 from $2,400 in the academic year beginning in the summer of 1993, not 1992.

title: Washington Heights Calm Shattered by Disruptions
description: An uneasy calm that prevailed yesterday in Washington Heights was shattered last night when a powerful firecracker injured two police officers, including a captain. In a separate incident, 14 demonstrators were arrested when they confronted officers half an hour later, the police said.

title: Review/Film; Bergman's Family Story Of Life Before Ingmar
description: "The Best Intentions," the epic-length story of a Swedish couple's courtship and marriage, is dominated by an unborn child. The baby whose arrival is imminent as the film concludes will be Ingmar Bergman, whose screenplay looks back at the social, economic and personal forces that turned his parents' early years together into a tug of war.

title: Reds-Red Sox Trade
description: The Cincinnati Reds acquired left-hander TOM BOLTON yesterday from the Boston Red Sox for outfielder BILLY HATCHER.

title: Some Apt Comedy in Cabarets
description: The Democratic National Convention is sparking a surge of political comedy in New York clubs.

title: Pirates Still Can't Solve Reds
description: Reds 5, Pirates 2

title: Eric Sevareid, 79, Is Dead; Commentator and Reporter
description: Eric Sevareid, a radio and television correspondent who became one of the country's most respected reporters and commentators, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 79 years old.

title: BRAZIL AND BANKS REACH AGREEMENT ON REDUCING DEBT
description: Brazil, the largest debtor in the developing world, and its creditor banks agreed yesterday on a series of steps to reduce its $44 billion debt and provide the country with lower interest rates and new longer-term loans.

title: Oases for the Politics-Parched Soul
description: Following the advice of Omar Khayyam, let us not waste time on the convention that can better be spent in the bar. The messy spectacle of the political arena requires a certain philosophical distance that only a good drink in a cool, ill-lighted place can provide. Fortunately, Manhattan has places where the roar of public life recedes to a faint murmur, and the din of partisan politics fades to a civilized buzz.

title: Texas Gives Harrah One to Remember
description: Rangers 14, Indians 4

title: As State After State Resumes Executions, U.S. Death-Penalty Law Is Still in Limbo
description: It may be some small comfort to David Ronald Chandler that when Congress finally passed death penalty legislation in 1988, it neglected to specify just how a Federal execution should be carried out.

title: Suffolk Budget Deficit Is Slashed To $50 Million, Gaffney Says
description: The Suffolk County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney, announced today that a re assessment of the county's deficit showed it was not $91 million in the red. Instead, he said, the hole was around $50 million.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Wife; 1985 Crusade by Tipper Gore Is Likely to Help 1992 Ticket
description: When Tipper Gore began a campaign against violent and sexually explicit lyrics on record albums seven years ago, her crusade was widely viewed as an inappropriate call for censorship.

title: George Sawyer Sr., 66, Scientist and Educator
description: Dr. George C. Sawyer Sr., a chemical engineer and drug developer who became an executive, professor and proponent of corporate social responsibility, died July 2 at the Butterfield Hospital in Cold Spring, N.Y. He was 66 years old and lived in Garrison, N.Y.

title: A Legislator Is Challenging Sen. Marino
description: Days after the legislative session in Albany ended in discord and disarray, the Republican Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, got some more bad news, at home: He is facing his first significant Democratic challenger in years.

title: Another Native Son Returns in Coffin
description: For years residents of this town have been accustomed to seeing its sons returned in coffins from a life of drugs and adventure in New York. But they insisted today that the case of Luis Jose Garcia, a 23-year-old whose shooting by a police officer last week sparked days of turmoil in Washington Heights, was different.

title: Gunmen in Flatbush Wound 3 at Corner
description: Two men climbed out of a car and began firing on a Brooklyn street corner where more than a dozen children were playing double dutch and cooling off in an open fire hydrant about 8 P.M. yesterday, the police and witnesses said.

title: Dining Nominees: Something for Everyone
description: Restaurants around New York City have been shoring up their vessels for the invasion of conventioneers that begins this weekend. For weeks, city residents have been hearing dire reports of daily gridlock, overflowing sidewalks and dining rooms that make Gov. Bill Clinton's headquarters look like a gentlemen's chess club.

title: Constellation Prize: Kelly and Cone Named To the All-Star Squads
description: Roberto Kelly did not expect to be named to the American League All-Star team. Not after a torturous, monthlong slump dropped his batting average below .290. Not with the way Mel Hall was hitting and the way Melido Perez was pitching.

title: At Home Abroad; Hope Turned to Dust
description: Even a world inured to television pictures of gaunt famine victims should care about the devastation menacing the southern third of Africa. Eleven countries, with a population of more than 120 million, are living under a drought previously unknown to the region in its sweep and severity.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Finances; Where the 'Soft Money' Comes From
description: Wall Street and the oil and gas industries have been the largest contributors to the Democratic and Republican parties in the current election cycle, followed by the insurance, tobacco and real estate industries, according to a new study published today.

title: Sports of The Times; The Name Of the Game Is Freeman
description: THE GOAL POSTS are up, the artificial field has been rolled out like linoleum and the blocking dummies, hunched in the shade nearby, await attack. "All the toys are in place," said Dick Steinberg, the general manager of the Jets, seated yesterday in his office beside the practice area here. "We just need the bodies."

title: Don't Blame the Juries for Liability Awards
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Scud' Remark Draws Rebuke
description: A police officer in Brooklyn was suspended yesterday for transmitting over a department radio frequency what officials said was an insensitive remark regarding Washington Heights.

title: Trenton Grows Uneasy as Personnel Whets Ax
description: The state Department of Personnel said today that it was not close to figuring out what state workers would be losing their jobs starting July 31.

title: Yanks Slam Mariners Early, Then Tremble at the End
description: Yankee batters were uncertain if they should drool or shudder when facing Randy Johnson of Seattle at the Stadium last night. Should they be anxious or afraid against the tall Mariners left-hander? His pitches seemed hittable, but some were headed who knows where. Swing or duck?

title: What to Watch As the Country Waits
description: Here is a schedule of television coverage of the Democratic National convention and related programming in the New York region. Sunday

title: Accounts
description: * Brooks Shoe, Rockford, Mich., to Griffin Bacal Inc., New York, to develop worldwide advertising for the athletic footwear manufacturer and place media in the United States. Billings on the account, previously at BBDO Chicago, were estimated at $6 million.

title: Nature, It Turns Out, Made a Molecule Long Before People Did
description: Carbon-based molecules shaped like soccer balls have fascinated chemists since the first one was synthesized seven years ago. Now for the first time these molecules, fullerenes, have been found in nature, lodged in rock that seems to date from the dawn of life on our planet.

title: Frederic Matys Thursz, Abstract Painter, 62
description: Frederic Matys Thursz, an abstract painter of monochromatic canvases, died last Saturday at University Hospital in Cologne, Germany. He was 62 years old and lived in Paris. He also had a studio in Ossining, N.Y.

title: Thompson Retires
description: DALEY THOMPSON retired from track and field yesterday after his last-minute bid to gain a place on Britain's team for the Barcelona Games ended in failure. The two-time gold medalist and world record-holder pulled up injured in the first event of a decathlon set up specially for him.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11 FOREBODING IN SARAJEVO

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY OFFICERS CHARGED IN THEFT AND SALE OF FAKE BAGS

title: Review/Music; Tchaikovsky Warhorses Are Spurred by Masur
description: For years, those associated with the New York Philharmonic complained that the orchestra was unfairly judged. It had to play week in and week out in a problematic hall, the argument went, while other orchestras would hit and run, rehearsing a program to a fare-thee-well and trotting it out in the acoustic luxury of Carnegie Hall to inevitable acclaim. Yet when the Philharmonic did get a crack at Carnegie under festival conditions, for the reopening of the hall after renovation in 1986 or the centennial celebration in 1991, the result was Philharmonic business as usual.

title: Topics of The Times; Footenote
description: He was a giant of the advertising industry, who helped build one of the world's largest advertising agencies and then went on to lead another. But Emerson Foote, who died this week at the age of 85, stood tallest on the occasions he risked that career to protect public health.

title: Status on Cummings
description: San Antonio Spurs forward TERRY CUMMINGS injured a knee and could miss the entire season, The San Antonio Express-News reported yesterday. The newspaper report said that Cummings tore two ligaments in his right knee when another player fell on him Monday during a pickup game in Chicago. Cummings was seen on crutches Tuesday night at San Antonio International Airport, according to the newspaper report.

title: Western Hanover Appears to Be the Steadiest Shot
description: A trip to the winner's circle tonight at the $1 million Meadowlands Pace would cap a splendid six-day spell for Gene Riegle, who was inducted into the Harness Racing Hall of Fame last Sunday.

title: DEKALB ENERGY WILL SELL MOST U.S. OIL AND GAS LINES
description: The Dekalb Energy Company agreed to sell nearly all of its American oil and gas operations to a unit of the Louis Dreyfus Energy Corporation, Wilton, Conn. Dekalb declined to disclose terms, but it said it would take a second-quarter net charge of about $28 million, or $2.90 a share, on the sale. Once the sale closes, Dekalb Energy said, it will have received gross proceeds and other consideration of about $121 million on the sale and smaller transactions that closed today with Berco Resources Inc. and Central Resources Inc. Dekalb will use the funds to reduce its nearly $150 million of debt and for other purposes.

title: What the Court Ruled On in Kidnap Case
description: To the Editor:

title: A Costly Show
description: Three days before the Democratic National Convention opens, the financial reality of gathering in New York City has sunk in. Page B1.

title: The Council's Garbage Test
description: New York's City Council, ever demanding to be taken seriously, has six more weeks to meet a major responsibility or duck. If it ducks, it will be jeopardizing the city's health and future through cowardice.

title: Making a Case for a Fiscal Jolt
description: Could fiscal policy, long buried under the rubble of the $4 trillion Federal debt, rise from the grave?

title: Mexican Observers Say State Elections Are Unfair
description: On the eve of two important state elections, a coalition of Mexican observer groups said today that the process would be neither free nor fair.

title: June Retail Sales Sputtered; Big Chains Posted 3.1% Rise
description: Retail sales in June continued to limp along at an uninspired pace, failing to give merchants a clear indication of what their prospects will be later this year.

title: Not Tuition Rise, a $500 'Quality Fee'
description: Trenton State College wants to claim its $1 million share of a state fund set up to reward colleges that keep tuition increases low.

title: Review/Theater; Shakespeare In the Park, Funny, Free But a Bit Wet
description: In the Forest of Arden, it is love that flowers above all else. But when the New York Shakespeare Festival opened its 30th-anniversary season on Wednesday night with "As You Like It" as the 20th presentation of its Shakespeare Marathon, love -- like the trees and greenery of Central Park that frame the Delacorte Theater -- bloomed in the rain.

title: Big Saudi Bank Assails Fed's Moves Against It
description: Saudi Arabia's largest bank, the National Commercial Bank, today characterized Federal regulators' moves against it as "devoid of any substance."

title: Maradona Eyes France
description: Argentina's idle soccer star, DIEGO MARADONA, said yesterday that he might continue his professional career in France if the Italian club Naples releases him from his contract. The 31-year-old World Cup hero, banned from the sport for 15 months for failing a drug test, told a local news agency that after a stint in France he would like to finish with the Buenos Aires first division team Boca Juniors, with which he originally made his name. (Reuter)

title: Humana May Split Insurance and Hospital Parts
description: Humana Inc., the big hospital and health insurance company, said yesterday that it might split into two separate businesses, signaling the failure of an integrated health-care strategy that analysts said might have been ahead of its time.

title: COMPANY NEWS: Neckwear by J. Garcia; Button-Down Man Meets A Rock Legend, Sort Of
description: For more than two decades, Jerry Garcia, the lead guitarist of the Grateful Dead, has serenaded legions of faithful followers -- many of whom favor tie-dyed T-shirts. Now aging Deadheads can dress up with some of Mr. Garcia's artistry.

title: New Jersey Trivia Exits the Turnpike
description: RONALD MAYER and Gerald Tomlinson are tackling a beast that many have failed to conquer: the New Jersey image.

title: Art in Review
description: 'National Showcase' Alternative Museum 594 Broadway, (near Houston Street) SoHo Through Aug. 1

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Behind the Scenes; The Other Albert Gore Watches Proudly From Tennessee
description: After a lunch of clam chowder and crackers today Albert Gore Sr. sat at his kitchen table and watched the television in proud silence as his son and namesake accepted an invitation to become the Democratic nominee for Vice President.

title: F.C.C. Devising Plan to License Future Phones
description: In a step toward authorizing a new generation of pocket-sized telephones and hand-held computers that communicate over the air, the Federal Communications Commission is drawing up a plan to award a handful of nationwide and regional radio licenses for "personal communication services."

title: Review/Art; Some Fragile Old Works From the New World
description: The Baroque art of colonial Colombia and Ecuador -- or the Vice-Royalty of Nueva Granada, as it was called for most of the 18th century -- is making a rare appearance in New York. The place is the Americas Society on Park Avenue; the show is a solemn yet exuberant mixture of religious paintings, portraiture, sculpture, silver liturgical implements and secular objects under the title "Barroco de la Nueva Granada: Colonial Art From Colombia and Ecuador."

title: CHRYSLER TO INVEST $110 MILLION IN NEW ENGINE
description: Chrysler said it would invest $110 million at its Trenton, Mich., engine plant to prepare to produce a 2-liter engine for a planned new small car. The car, code-named PL, will be available in early 1994. The new 16-valve engine will replace 2.2-liter and 2.5-liter engines made at Trenton. Production of the new engine will begin this fall. Chrysler said its investment covers machinery and equipment for the new engine.

title: Slowly, Plan to Aid Russia Gains Support in the House
description: Although President Bush reassured President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia this week that Washington would support his economic reform program, the Administration's Russian aid package, which finally passed the Senate last week, still faces an uphill battle for approval in the House.

title: An Unequal Justice; Little Aid for Hard-Time Sisterhood
description: T. J. Rivera lingered remorsefully over her role in one of the most startling social turns of America's last decade -- a tripling of the number of women in United States prisons and jails, a growth rate well beyond that of male inmates.

title: Continental Takes Offer By Investor
description: Continental Airlines took a big step in pulling itself out of bankruptcy yesterday by agreeing to accept a $350 million investment from Charles E. Hurwitz, a controversial Houston entrepreneur, in exchange for a majority stake in the company.

title: Why Is Public Transit In New York a Mess?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: On the Trail; AGAIN, PEROT ADDS TO PRESS OPERATION
description: Apologizing to reporters for a second time this week, a top aide to Ross Perot said today that the Presidential campaign organization was beefing up its press operation. Thomas W. Luce 3d, chairman of the Perot Petition Committee, today announced the hiring as a press liaison of Elizabeth Maas, a public relations specialist who has worked for Republican candidates.

title: Leading Executive Resigns From Subaru of America
description: Thomas R. Gibson, the president and chief operating officer of Subaru of America Inc., resigned unexpectedly today to head a Philadelphia company that manages arenas, stadiums and convention centers.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Wednesday about a Manhattan parade of participants in Op Sail misidentified the marchers shown. They were Chileans from the training ship Esmeralda, not Argentines.

title: Officers Arrested in Theft of Chanel Bags
description: Four New York City police officers and two retired ones were charged yesterday with stealing and then fencing thousands of counterfeit Chanel handbags that had been seized by the Manhattan District Attorney in February.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Hatalsky Leads on a 65 Morris Hatalsky, long known as one of the best putters on the PGA Tour, outdid himself in yesterday's opening round of the Anheuser-Busch Golf Classic in Williamsburg, Va. Hatalsky, who got the last of his four victories in 1990, one-putted the first 12 holes en route to a six-under-par 65 and a one-shot lead over Ed Dougherty, Frank Conner, Ed Humenik, David Peoples and Peter Persons. Hatalsky finished with 16 one-putts and a pair of two-putts. His total of 20 was two off the tour's one-round record, shared by Kenny Knox, Andy North, Mike McGee and Sam Trahan. (AP) Englishman Shoots a 60: Paul Curry of England shot a 10-under-par 60 yesterday, the lowest round ever in a professional event in Britain, and earned a share of the lead at the halfway point of the Scottish Open in Gleneagles. Curry had two eagles, seven birdies and one bogey and became only the sixth player -- but third in eight days -- to shoot 60 on the European tour. Darren Clarke of Northern Ireland and Johan Rystrom of Sweden both did it in Monte Carlo last week. Mark Brooks of the United States shot a seven-under 63 in his second trip over the 6,739-yard King's course and was tied with Curry at 12-under 128. (AP) TENNIS Ivanisevic Wins Twice Top-seeded Petr Korda was upset yesterday at the Swiss Open, but Goran Ivanisevic showed his versatility by winning two matches in one day on the clay courts in Gstaad less than a week after serving his way into the Wimbledon final. Ivanisevic, seeded third, eliminated Claudio Mezzadri, 6-4, 7-6 (7-3), in a first-round match and then beat a qualifier, Girts Dzelde, 6-3, 6-3. Fabrice Santoro upset Korda, 1-6, 7-5, 6-2, in the second round. Second-seeded Michael Chang struggled past Cedric Pioline, 3-6, 7-6 (7-4), 7-5. (AP) Shelton Rallies: The defending champion, Bryan Shelton, saved a match point in the second set and went on to defeat Arne Thoms, 4-6, 7-6 (7-3), 6-2, in the second round of the Hall of Fame Championships, being played on grass courts in Newport, R.I. Sandon Stolle beat No. 2 Gianluca Pozzi, 6-1, 4-6, 6-3, and Javier Frana, the runner-up last year, defeated No. 8 Simon Youl, 3-6, 6-4, 7-5. (AP)

title: For the People, Kennedy; for Jurors, Kennedy!
description: It had been 10 minutes, perhaps 20, since Justice Carol Berkman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan began a lecture she had given many times before: Trial by Jury 101.

title: Council Postpones Action on Garbage Plan
description: With a majority of New York City Council members pledged to oppose the Dinkins administration's long-range plan for garbage disposal, Council leaders yesterday pushed through a monthlong extension of a deadline to give them time to reach a compromise with the administration.

title: Plant Expansion Project Near Swamp Is Criticized
description: Morris County conservationists are calling it the Second Battle of the Great Swamp, and as with so many sequels, the issues are not as clear cut as they were the first time around.

title: Private-Sector Grants Given For a New Breed of Schools
description: Grants were awarded today by a private foundation set up by business leaders last year at the request of President Bush to finance a "new generation" of American schools. Awards went to 11 design teams, including two New York-based groups.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Wasserstein Tests the Water

title: Edwards Air Force Base Journal; Watching Space Ships, And History, in a Desert
